image.altText: A woman holds an Airtag in her hand near her bag.

items.synopsis: Apple's Airtags and similar devices like Tile are marketed as useful tools for people to keep track of their belongings. But domestic violence awareness groups claim in the wrong hands, the devices can be used to track people against their wishes.

title.children: 'One is more horrific than the next': When women discovered they'd been stalked with Airtags, they took their fight to Apple

image.altText: A black and white photo of a topless person from their right side.

items.synopsis: A straightforward portrait of artist Emma Armstrong-Porter with "a lot of stuff going on" underneath its simplicity is selected as this year's National Photographic Portrait Prize winner.

title.children: 'Simple' photo taken in a home studio wins 2023 National Photographic Portrait Prize

image.altText: A man with white hair and glasses smiles.

items.synopsis: John Feint has volunteered with the St Vincent de Paul Society for 16 years, and in that time started a program offering some fun to at-risk youth.

title.children: John created a program bringing Scouts and Vinnies together to support at-risk teenagers

items.synopsis: Fifteen Canberra suburbs, as well as Googong across the border, fell out of the $1 million zone over the past year — their median houses prices are now six figures.

title.children: Almost half of Canberra's houses are still worth more than $1 million despite nationwide fall in prices

image.altText: A group of men walk forward at a men's ceremony in Wadeye.

items.synopsis: Bruised and traumatised, resilient and proud — how the troubled outback community of Wadeye in the Northern Territory is trying to shed its violent past and move forward.

title.children: ‘They all burned, all the houses’: A bush town in anguish tries to heal from its violent past

image.altText: Composite image of a woman with long hair as she looks now and short hair as she looked in the past with photos of four babies.

items.synopsis: Journalist Quentin McDermott — who secured the first interview with Kathleen Folbigg from prison — gives an insight into Australian Story's investigation of her case over 20 years.

title.children: How Australian Story's coverage of Kathleen Folbigg's case helped kickstart the scientific research that ultimately freed her

image.altText: Travis Head fumbles the ball as he dives forward on the ground comically

items.synopsis: England's approach to Test cricket was always going to provide some hectic moments in the Ashes, and so it proved on day one of the first Test.

title.children: Five things we learned on day one of the Ashes as England's start stuns their skipper

image.altText: Anthony Albanese speaking at Victorian Labor Conference.

items.synopsis: The prime minister announces a $2 billion one-off investment — which will be distributed among the states and territories within the next two weeks — during a speech at the Victorian Labor Conference.

title.children: Albanese has announced a $2 billion investment in social housing

image.altText: Philip Lowe, wearing a dark suit, stands at a lectern in front of a large projection of a line graph

items.synopsis: There's a veritable shopping list of economic elements that will need to move in "right" direction for the RBA to stop lifting interest rates, but there's only one number that can seal the deal for cheaper borrowing costs in a concrete way, writes David Taylor.

title.children: The RBA will eventually stop raising interest rates. Here's what it will take to get to that point

image.altText: Side by side photos of politicians Lidia Thorpe, David Van, Peter Dutton and Brittany Higgins, all looking serious

items.synopsis: The way both Brittany Higgins's and Lidia Thorpe's complaints of sexual assault erupted reflected their lack of belief that Parliament House, and/or politics, would deal seriously with them, writes Laura Tingle.

title.children: The Coalition's political attack seems to have backfired, but it's women at the heart of allegations that suffer most

image.altText: Bradley Lyons stands in front of a white wall looking straight ahead in a passport-style photograph.

items.synopsis: When Bradley Lyons lay down on his bed for an afternoon nap after working the early Sunday shift at a Lakes Entrance supermarket in December 2018, he was blissfully unaware that several people were conspiring to kill him.

title.children: Justice for young dad tortured by 'vigilantes', executed and left in a shallow grave, as seventh person is convicted

image.altText: A small brown mushroom sprouts from dark green grass

items.synopsis: While very few patients are expected to access new psychedelic therapies when regulatory changes take effect next month, medicinal cannabis companies, drug developers and health insurers are keeping watch on the emerging industry.

title.children: Rules around psychedelics are about to change, and an unsurprising player is entering the market

image.altText: Marnus Labuschagne jumps up close to the pitch as Jonny Bairstow completes a sweep shot

items.synopsis: It came as promised, England's ultra-attacking new 'Bazball' tactic. Australia knew it was coming, and the unexpected response of Pat Cummins's could be the deciding factor of the whole Ashes series.

title.children: Australia got its first good look at Bazball. Its response will decide the Ashes

image.altText: Screenshot1

items.synopsis: The Sussex crowd is left in raptures as T20 Blast debutant Brad Currie takes one of the most spectacular catches in cricket history.

title.children: 'He can't quite believe it': Is this the best catch in the history of cricket?

image.altText: A young, smartly dressed blonde woman has one hand on a desk, the other pointing in the air

items.synopsis: Prima Facie won the Australian playwright an Olivier, plus Jodie Comer a Tony just this week, but beyond awards, the powerful “rape play” has far-reaching implications for the law.

title.children: An outsider to the law and to theatre, Suzie Miller wrote a play that’s changing the legal system

image.altText: A man in silhouette stands near a boat on a beach, looking out to sea at during a pink and gold sunset.

items.synopsis: The mayor of Palm Island in North Queensland says the telco's arrival is "great news" for the remote Indigenous community that will create jobs and launch the island into the "corporate world".

title.children: Half of this remote island has no internet — but it is about  to host Telstra's newest call centre

image.altText: A fit older white man with dark glasses and white hair smiles as he signs autographs for fans on a golf course.

items.synopsis: A lawyer for the Normans denies the pair breached their duty of care amid accusations the former golfer and his wife provided alcoholic beverages to minors and did not prevent "abusive conduct" at a party at their home.

title.children: Greg Norman and wife sued for negligence after allegations pool party led to underage drinking and sexual assault

image.altText: Gino Mader

items.synopsis: Swiss rider Gino Mäder has died after crashing into a ravine on the descent towards the finish line in Thursday's stage five of the Tour de Suisse, his team Bahrain Victorious said on Friday.

title.children: Cyclist Gino Mäder dies after ravine crash during stage five of the Tour de Suisse

image.altText: Heather Mack carried her baby daughter inside a cell. She's got long curly brown hair and is wearing an orange vest.

items.synopsis: A US woman accused of helping to kill her mother and stuff her body in a suitcase during a luxury Bali vacation changes her plea to guilty in a Chicago federal court.

title.children: US woman pleads guilty over Bali 'suitcase' murder

image.altText: Ukrainian servicemen look under debris in a street for booby-traps.

items.synopsis: Ukraine is covered in more landmines, booby traps and unexploded ordnance than any other country in the world. As the conflict rages on, what resources and innovations will help the de-mining community tackle the issue?

title.children: New 'jumping' explosives and booby-trapped toys. What Ukraine is facing as the world's most mined country

image.altText: 8 men in 1940s casual attire lean against wood hut in pow camp Nangwarry SA

items.synopsis: A few old slabs of concrete buried deep in pine forests are all that remain of south-east South Australia's prisoner of war camps. But their history is being uncovered by new research that shines a light on the stories of the men interned in the region.

title.children: How Italian prisoners of war and Australian families kept 'strong bonds' of friendship after WWII

image.altText: A mid-shot of a woman wearing spectacles and a pink and purple jumper smiles for a photo standing outside a house.

items.synopsis: Perth resident Stephanie Chu has called WA home for almost 20 years, but is ineligible to sign local petitions because she is a non-citizen. It is a situation that has left her and many others feeling powerless in their own community.

title.children: Stephanie owns her home and pays rates, but 'unfair' council rules have left her feeling voiceless

image.altText: A small marsupial mole in cupped hands

items.synopsis: The marsupial mole is completely blind, "swims" through the desert sand and rarely ventures above ground. But one eagle-eyed traveller is in "disbelief" after spotting one attempting to cross the road.

title.children: 'Very rarely seen' marsupial with 'silky' golden fur spotted near Uluru

items.synopsis: A McDonald's manager who was punched and spat on by a customer tells the Adelaide Magistrates Court he still has flashbacks of the incident and has to attend therapy sessions.

title.children: 'Absolutely disgusted': Victims of McDonald's 'rampage' tell court of trauma

image.altText: A composite of three people - a young man, a young woman and and older man.

items.synopsis: The man police believe is behind a fatal attack in the English city of Nottingham will face court over the weekend as thousands gather to mourn the victims.

title.children: Police charge Nottingham attack suspect with three counts of murder

image.altText: A woman holds a sign at a protest reading: "With You"

items.synopsis: The revision is part of a revamping of laws related to sex crimes, with the parliament also passing a new law to increase awareness of LGBTQ+ issues, which activists criticise for not guaranteeing equal rights for sexual minorities.

title.children: Japan raises age of sexual consent from 13 to 16 after public outrage over rape acquittals

image.altText: View from an elevated tower where two people are on a zipline.

items.synopsis: It's famed for its spectacular views, stunning bushwalks and adrenaline-inducing bike rides. But Hobart's kunanyi/Mt Wellington could become the site of a new thrillseeking tourism experience — one that's already attracting critics.

title.children: Critics 'appalled' at proposal for 1.3km zipline on kunanyi/Mount Wellington

image.altText: A wicketkeeper pulls a face off 'close but no cigar'

items.synopsis: England A piles on the runs against Australia in Leicester, after the Aussies were all out for 284 in the first innings.

title.children: Australia looks for positives as England A dominates warm-up match ahead of women's Ashes

image.altText: A man in black plays a golf shot.

items.synopsis: With his sister already a US Open champion, Min Woo Lee makes his run at the leaders with a stunning round in Los Angeles.

title.children: Min Woo Lee rockets up the leaderboard at US Open to give Aussies hope of glory

image.altText: Ocean Swagman live export vessel

items.synopsis: It’s estimated up to 40 per cent of the world’s live export ships are now operating from South America, with cattle being shipped to a range of countries include Ukraine.

title.children: Live cattle export trade from South America 'red hot': What could this mean for Australia?
